description.narrative:
Empowering Citizens Through Alternative Education project for OHKs funding support focuses on providing alternative education modelusing REFLECT methodology to 240 beneficiaries (50% girls and young women), through which the beneficiaries would acquire basic reading and writing skills, enhanced awareness that both men and women have equal rights and opportunities (education, health, participation and access to resources and information, sexual and reproductive health rights), and engaging in income generation activities as a result of the skills acquired in the REFLECT circle (meaning class meetings).
The local implementing partner of this project will be NANA (Associacao de Apoio ao Desenvolvimento). They will support and monitor the day-to-day implementation of the project in coordination with relevant stakeholders in the 2 districts (Mocuba and Lugela) where the project is going to be implemented. NANA isnot for profit, national development entity which was founded in February 1998. It is a legalentity with administrative, financial and patrimonial autonomy. It is composed of 32 youth of both sexes. The organization has Zambezia province as its operational area and is implementing various projects on governance on agriculture, education for active citizenship, health and institutional development. It is recognized as a development organization bythe government at district, provincial and national level.
NANA has interventions in the districts of Mocuba, Lugela, Alto Molócuè and Maganja da Costa. Its activities started in the City of Mocuba by a groupof students from Mocuba secondary school who committed themselves to tackling environmental degradation that was increasingly becoming a cause for concern in the city. Over the last few years, NANA has expanded its intervention areas to cover, beside tackling environmental issues, they have interventions on Health, HIV / AIDS, Education, child support and protection and Good Governance. NANAalso prioritizes, advocacy, networking and capacity building of other Civil Society Organizations at local level. They are an active member of 2 powerful civil society forums in education; FEDUZA (Forum for Civil Society in the Education in Zambezia) at provincial level and MEPT (Movement of Education for All) at national level.
NANA and its partners work to ensure that human rights are respected, protected and upheld as a primary responsibility of the state. NANA has a 5 year strategic plan for the period (2016-2020). This strategic plan embraced some changes that have been embraced within the organization. They are focussing more on human rights basedinterventions that empowers local communities to be part of an inclusive and participative governance at all levels. Its main pillars are; 1. governance for citizenship, 2. alternatives to governance for agriculture and natural resources, 3. governance for health and 4. institutional development. The first and second pillars responds and aligns well with 2 Oxfam Impact goals of; 1. Advancing accountable politics for better public services and increased food security and 2. Transforming social norms so that young women can flourish. In partnership with NANA, OXFAM is empowering communities especially young women and adult women to claim and enjoy their rights as citizens through formal and non-formal education.

participating-org.narrative:
NANA is a non-profit, private development legal entity with legal personality with administrative, financial and patrimonial autonomy. It gathers 32 young members of both sexes. The organization is of provincial scope, with its soothes in the City of Mocuba, street Robert Mugabe, founded the 14 of February of 1998.
NANA is implementing its programs in the Districts of Mocuba, Lugela and AltoMolócuè. And began its activities in the City of Mocuba through a students initiatives from Mocuba Secondary School who were concerned about problems that were emanating from environmental degradation. Over the last few years NANA has expanded its base of intervention, covering, in addition to the environmental area, they have also included Health, HIV / AIDS, Education, child protection andsupport and Good Governance. In its intervention NANA also prioritizes the interaction and capacity building of other Civil SocietyOrganizations at the local level. They also engage the responsible authorities to ensure thatthey are accountable to their electorate and the citizens they serve. They also empower the communities to demand their rights from those who have the responsibility to provide services to them.
NANA and its partners work to ensure that human rights are respected, protected and held as the primary responsibility of the state. Their current strategic plan covers the period (2016-2021) and have two approved statutes, one of them was published in the government gazette. The other one was published as NANA-Nucleus of Friends of Nature and Environment and there is the other one that repeals the first, which is in the process of its publication where the name NANA features to mean The Organisation for Development Support. This was approved by the organization's General Assembly on February 14, 2013. Rights and social, political and economic well-being for all, ensured by inclusive and participatory governance.
NANA's mission statement underpins its contribution to social, political and economic well-being and fulfillment of community rights using integrated approaches based onhuman rights, gender and communication strategies for social and behavior change.
The main target groups for NANA are as follows: # Women and young men and adults of bothsexes of working age # Children and adolescents from 0 to 18 years of age # Institutions such as: Advisory Councils, Change Agents, REFLECT Circles, Girl's School Clubs, District Platforms, Agriculture based groupings such as, livestock associations, Children's Parliament, Youth Parliament, Peer Review, School Committees, Co-management Committees and Community Based Organizations.
The theory of change that informs its work emphasizes on the belief that NANA can bring about significant and sustainable changes to the achievement of its vision and mission by combining the following approaches and strategies: (i) The Human Rights Based Approach; (ii) The approach using the Socio-Ecological Model; (iii) The Gender Approach.
The human rights-based approach of NANA is based on the universal declaration of human rights and on treaties and conventions signed and ratified by states and comprises 3 basic pillars: (1) Community Empowerment; (ii) The Development of Partnerships and (iii) The Monitoring and Advocacy of Governance.
NANA- Associação de Apoio ao Desenv
